key_title: Key to the species of Verbena

source.author: Conn, B.J.
source.title: Verbenaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 4. Cornaceae to Asteraceae
source.citation: From: Conn, B.J. (1999). Verbenaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 4. Cornaceae to Asteraceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Leaves sessile, amplexicaul to semi-amplexicaul and somewhat cordate at base
Leaves petiolate or narrowly tapering into a cuneate or attenuate subsessile base
Stems mostly glabrous except in younger parts
Bracts shorter than, equal to or slightly longer than calyx; corolla-tube up to 2 times longer than calyx
Bracts conspicuously longer than calyx; corolla-tube c. 3 times longer than calyx
Calyx to c. 3 mm long; corolla limb 1.5–5 mm diam.; ultimate divisions of leaves c. triangular or ovate
Calyx long-tubular, 6–9 mm long; corolla limb 8–10 mm diam.; ultimate divisions of leaves narrow-linear
Calyx distinctly 5-toothed; erect or ascending perennial; corolla-tube 2–5 mm long
Calyx 4-toothed; procumbent annual; corolla-tube 1.5–2 mm long
Lower leaves deeply pinnately lobed, pinnatifid or pinnatisect; spikes 10–35(–40) cm long, not contracted
Lower leaves serrate-dentate, neither pinnatifid nor pinnatisect; spikes (1–)2–8(–10) cm long, somewhat contracted
Arrangement of flowers in spikes distant in lower half of rachis; hairs on rachis, bracts and calyx closely appressed; bracts ovate, often shorter than calyx; lamina with both rounded and acute teeth
Arrangement of flowers in spikes close to each other along rachis; hairs on rachis, bracts and calyx spreading; bracts narrow-lanceolate, equal to or longer than calyx; lamina with acute teeth
